Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 02:47PM AmyMarie89 wrote: Thanks for all of your posts.  I do agree that there are good and bad.  Some of the good includes: I have been on birth control for about 19 years.  It has been a combination of the higher hormone pills such as good old OrthoNovum 777 which was my first oral contraceptive and then the shot and now for about the past 8-10 years I have been on Lutera (Alesse).  If there is a lower hormone pill (such as Ortho Tri-cyclen Lo) I am hoping maybe my GP will put me on.  But then again, might be to late to change?
Posts.Title: EXTENDED ORAL CONTRACEPTIVE USE & BREAST CANCER...RELATED? AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: AmyMarie89 wrote: Does anyone know if extended use of oral contraceptives (I'm talkin years of use) is related to breast cancer or is considered a 'risk'?  I am curious because when I went to see my GP about the lumps I felt above my breast (lymph nodes/cysts) the first thing she asked me was if I was on birth control. Posts.Title: EXTENDED ORAL CONTRACEPTIVE USE & BREAST CANCER...RELATED? AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: AmyMarie89 wrote: In my original post  "Swollen Lymph Node Near Armpit....Now Found Second One...Concerns?", I was skeptical of being able to go through with an US...well, things have changed.  I was going to wait until after I was married (this Christmas) to get my Ultrasound (US) once I had insurance through my husband.  After considering the pros and cons, I got off my butt and did some serious research to try to get my US for a lower cost or for free.  I think it was the waiting game and living with not knowing that got to me, for I need piece-of-mind. I went onto the Susan G. Komen website and called their phone number.  They had many resources where low cost and even free services for women and breast care were available.  It took almost all afternoon but finally I found a hospital about a half hour away that offers those services.  I told the lady my situation and she took my information.  She said it would take less than 2 weeks to get an appointment and she would call me with my appointment time.  I asked her to please tell me how much I can look forward to spending for the US....she told me it was FREE!  I definitly was not expecting that, for I was expecting to pay at a lower cost but not free.  I am a happy camper now and I will keep you updated! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: GOT FREE ULTRASOUND! AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2009 03:39PM AmyMarie89 wrote: I want to thank you all for your well wishes and support. My wedding is planned for the week of Christmas this year.  With the normal US results, I can now consentrate (sp) on my future and a mammo at a later date is now sufficient. God Bless
Posts.Title: GOT FREE ULTRASOUND! AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 05:29AM AmyMarie89 wrote: Good Morning! Well, today is the day and I will be leaving to go to the hospital in about 45 minutes.  To my surprise, I am not nervous at all.  I do wish someone was with me but all in all, I think I am doing very well.  I slept good last night.  I think I am just anxious to get it done and over with and see what the report says.  My only concern is that if everything seems ok but I feel that a biopsy is needed, I will be turned down due to not being insured.  I have less power than those who are insured.  I am saying this due to the horrific stories I have heard about tests coming out negative with no biopsy/additional treatment recommended and when the woman says she wants to get a biopsy and it is done, they find atypical cells or cancer.  So these women find their own cancer.  Makes me question who I can trust anymore.  With the doctors knowing that these tests are not accurate, you would think THEY would be the one's stressing additional tests to support the diagnostic test results.  Instead, they put 100% confidence in these flawed tests and are misdiagnosing women who in fact DO have cancer.   SAD! I'll be back later on this afternoon to let ya know how it went!  (HUGS)
Posts.Title: GOT FREE ULTRASOUND! AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 02:04PM - edited Aug 18, 2009 02:06PM by AmyMarie89 Hello everyone I had my test today and the woman tech was very young (early 20's).  I was able to sit up during the procedure which took only 15 minutes.  I explained to her where I felt the abnormalities and she went straight to those areas with the wand.  Lucky enough, the radiologist was actually in the other room reading the images WHILE she was taking them.  The radiologist did not speak to me but through the tech and she said everything looked normal 'so far' but had to finish the report.  My GP and myself should have the results in 24 hours unlike the 2-3 day wait I was expecting. Even thought everything looked ok, the radiologist suggested I should still 'maybe' want to get a mammogram if I still feel questionable or uneasy.  It is up to me to get the script from my doctor.  I found out that the Susan G. Komen Fund will NOT cover a free mammogram if a US or MRI shows everything is ok.  The only way to get one is to have a positive result OR if everything is ok, the radiologist must put on the bottom of the report 'mammogram recommended'.  The tech said she is not sure if the radiologist will do that. If I get a clean bill of health through the US and the readiologist does NOT put anything on the report, I will go to the local YWCA and see if they can help me get a free mammo. If anything, the mammo can either confirm the US's negative results OR save my life. Once I get the report, I will go over it here with ya'll and get some imput of the technical terms if need be. God Bless
Posts.Title: GOT FREE ULTRASOUND! AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 06:05PM AmyMarie89 wrote: Hello Great news that my US came out that "No abnormalities are seen" on either side.  Also, the radiologist did put something on the report that says "If the patient has not yet had one, a  baseline mammogram would be appropriate for a patient of this age" I was informed that the hospital that performed the US also has monthly FREE well-women exams and mammograms so I am going to outweigh the pros and cons of getting one.  If not now, possibly get one after all the hooplah of my wedding.  Thanks for all the support!!!!! God Bless
Posts.Title: GOT FREE ULTRASOUND! AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2009 05:34PM AmyMarie89 wrote: Avea Just be glad that the doctor who performed the mammogram decided to have your US right away.  At your young age, a mammogram is not normally recommended until you are around 40 yrs old due to the density of younger womens' breast tissue (unless you are a high risk or have family history of breast cancer). I am a plus size woman, 37 and have a size C cup.  I am glad that my GP went straight to ordering a US.  My lymph nodes were swollen on the left side but now I feel them swollen on the right as well.  The left pectoral area has a harden cyst/node which I am concerned about even though my GP said I had nothing to worry about.  Since my area of concern is ABOVE the breast and not IN the breast, a mammogram would not pick up any of those areas.  I am still awaiting to hear when my US will be scheduled because I am going through a free-clinic.  It could take up to 2 weeks.
